message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest liver disease, and the laboratory studies show elevated liver enzymes. The liver biopsy shows plasma cell infiltration and periportal piecemeal necrosis, which are indicative of autoimmune hepatitis. Anti-smooth muscle antibodies are often present in autoimmune hepatitis. Anti-mitochondrial antibodies are typically present in primary biliary cirrhosis, which is not consistent with the patient’s symptoms. There is no indication for HBV testing, making option C incorrect. Elevated serum transferrin saturation is associated with hemochromatosis, which is not consistent with the patient’s symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and laboratory findings suggest autoimmune hepatitis. Among the options, positive anti-smooth muscle antibodies are associated with autoimmune hepatitis. Positive anti-mitochondrial antibodies are associated with primary biliary cholangitis, positive HBV surface antigen is associated with hepatitis B virus infection, and elevated serum transferrin saturation is associated with hemochromatosis.

Positive anti-mitochondrial antibodies are associated with primary biliary cirrhosis, which is not consistent with this patient’s presentation. We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and the elevated liver function tests suggest autoimmune hepatitis. The most likely finding would be positive anti-smooth muscle antibodies, which are seen in 50-70% of cases of autoimmune hepatitis. Anti-mitochondrial antibodies are seen in primary biliary cholangitis, hepatitis B surface antigen is seen in hepatitis B infection, and elevated serum transferrin saturation is seen in hereditary hemochromatosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The elevated liver enzymes and tenderness in the right upper quadrant suggest liver disease. The history of Hashimoto thyroiditis also suggests an autoimmune disorder. This raises the suspicion of autoimmune hepatitis, which is associated with Positive anti-smooth muscle antibodies. The other options are not associated with autoimmune hepatitis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has signs of liver dysfunction, and the liver biopsy shows plasma cell infiltration and areas of periportal piecemeal necrosis, which suggest autoimmune hepatitis. Positive anti-smooth muscle antibodies are commonly found in patients with autoimmune hepatitis. Positive anti-mitochondrial antibodies are found in patients with primary biliary cholangitis, which is less likely in this case. Positive HBV surface antigen is found in patients with acute or chronic hepatitis B, which is not likely in this case. Elevated serum transferrin saturation is a marker for iron overload, which is not likely in this case.
